perturbation.original_text: Section 1.6 Integrity shall be deemed to be an independent contractor and, except as specifically provided or authorized herein, shall have no authority to act for or represent the Fund.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 1.6 Integrity shall be deemed to be an independent contractor and, except as specifically provided or authorized herein, shall have the authority to act for or represent the Fund in all matters.
perturbation.explanation: By granting Integrity the blanket authority to act for or represent the Fund in 'all matters,' this clause contradicts the established definition of an 'independent contractor,' which typically limits the contractor's authority and control over the principal.
perturbation.law_explanation: The IRS uses a common-law test to determine worker classification. This test evaluates the degree of control and independence. Granting the contractor broad authority to represent the Fund blurs the lines between contractor and employee, potentially leading to misclassification under IRS guidelines.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 26 U.S. Code § 3121 - Definitions | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you Quick search by citation: Title Section Go! 26 U.S. Code § 3121 - Definitions U.S. Code Notes Authorities (CFR) prev | next (a) Wages For purposes of this chapter, the term “ wages ” means all remuneration for employment , including the cash value of all remuneration (including benefits) paid in any medium other than cash; except that such term shall not include— (1) in the case of the taxes imposed by sections 3101(a) and 3111(a) that part of the remuneration which, after remuneration (other than remuneration referred to in the succeeding paragraphs of this subsection) equal to the contribution and benefit base (as determined under section 230 of the Social Security Act ) with respect to employment has been paid to an individual by an employer during the calendar year with respect to which such contribution and benefit base is effective, is paid to such individual by such employer during such calendar year. perturbation.justification: The changed text grants Integrity 'the authority to act for or represent the Fund in all matters,' which significantly expands their control and authority. The Perturbation Explanation highlights that this contradicts the nature of an 'independent contractor.' The Law Explanation suggests this could lead to misclassification under IRS guidelines. While the provided law snippets (26 U.S. Code § 3121) focus on the definition of 'wages' and 'employment,' they implicitly address the employer-employee relationship. By granting Integrity such broad authority, the changed text blurs the lines between an independent contractor and an employee, suggesting a potentially stronger employer-employee relationship. Although the snippets don't directly define an independent contractor, the broad authority granted by the modified text raises concerns about proper classification for tax purposes, as alluded to in the Law Explanation. This warrants a high contradiction score, as the modification alters the fundamental nature of the relationship.

perturbation.original_text: Integrity may allow commissions or concessions to dealers in such amounts as Integrity shall determine from time to time, as set forth in the Fund's Registration Statement. Except as may otherwise be determined by Integrity and the Fund from time to time, such commissions or concessions shall be uniform to all dealers.
perturbation.changed_text: Integrity may allow commissions or concessions to dealers in such amounts as Integrity shall determine from time to time, as set forth in the Fund's Registration Statement. Such commissions or concessions shall be determined by Integrity alone, and need not be uniform to all dealers.
perturbation.explanation: This modification allows Integrity to offer non-uniform commissions. This creates a situation where some dealers could receive preferential treatment, potentially violating fair practice rules.
perturbation.law_explanation: FINRA Rule 2341(l)(3)(A) requires that 'no member shall offer or pay any discount, concession, or allowance to any dealer...which is not available to all dealers' under similar terms. Permitting non-uniform commissions directly violates this provision, creating potential liability for FINRA violations.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 2341. Investment Company Securities | FINRA.org Skip to main content 2341. Investment Company Securities (a) Application This Rule shall apply exclusively to the activities of members in connection with the securities of companies registered under the Investment Company Act; provided however, that Rule 2320 shall apply, in lieu of this Rule, to members' activities in connection with "variable contracts" as defined therein. (b) Definitions (1) The terms "affiliated member," "compensation," "cash compensation," "non-cash compensation" and "offeror" as used in paragraph (l) of this Rule shall have the following meanings: (A) "Affiliated Member" shall mean a member which, directly or indirectly, controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with a non-member company. (B) "Compensation" shall mean cash compensation and non-cash compensation. (C) "Cash compensation" shall mean any discount, concession, fee, service fee, commission, asset-based sales charge, loan, override or cash employee benefit received in connection with the sale and distribution of investment company securities. (D) "Non-cash compensation" shall mean any form of compensation received in connection with the sale and distribution of investment company securities that is not cash compensation, including but not limited to merchandise, gifts and prizes, travel expenses, meals and lodging. (E) "Offeror" shall mean an investment company, an adviser to an investment company, a fund administrator, an underwriter and any affiliated person (as defined in Section 2(a)(3) of the Investment Company Act) of such entities. (2) "Brokerage commissions," as used in paragraph (k), shall not be limited to commissions on agency transactions but shall include underwriting discounts or concessions and fees paid to members in connection with tender offers. (3) "Covered account," as used in paragraph (k), shall mean (A) any other investment company or other account managed by the investment adviser of such investment com
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: BrokerCheck - Find a broker, investment or financial advisor
perturbation.justification: The changed text allows Integrity to offer non-uniform commissions, while the original text states that these commissions should be uniform to all dealers unless otherwise determined. The Law Explanation refers to FINRA Rule 2341(l)(3)(A), which prohibits offering discounts or concessions to some dealers that aren't available to all under similar terms. Scraped Law Snippet 1 contains the text '2341. Investment Company Securities' and defines 'Cash compensation' as 'any discount, concession, fee, service fee, commission...'. While Snippet 1 doesn't explicitly state the prohibition in (l)(3)(A), the Law Explanation correctly links the allowance of non-uniform commissions to a potential violation of that rule. This creates a strong contradiction, as the changed text directly permits what the rule seems to prohibit, making the contradiction score 0.8.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the Principality of Sealand.
perturbation.explanation: This clause specifies that the contract will be governed by the laws of the Principality of Sealand. This is a problem because Sealand is not a recognized sovereign state and its laws are not legally binding or enforceable in US courts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Full Faith and Credit Clause, U.S. Constitution, Article IV, Section 1
perturbation.law_explanation: The Full Faith and Credit Clause requires states to respect the laws and judicial decisions of other states, and the federal government to respect those of the states. However, this clause does not extend to unrecognized entities like Sealand, making the contract unenforceable as it attempts to rely on a legal system that US courts will not recognize.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: Article IV | U.S. Constitution | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you Article IV Primary tabs Section 1. Full faith and credit shall be given in each state to the public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of every other state. And the Congress may by general laws prescribe the manner in which such acts, records, and proceedings shall be proved, and the effect thereof. Section 2. The citizens of each state shall be entitled to all privileges and immunities of citizens in the several states. A person charged in any state with treason, felony, or other crime, who shall flee from justice, and be found in another state, shall on demand of the executive authority of the state from which he fled, be delivered up, to be removed to the state having jurisdiction of the crime. No person held to service or labor in one state, under the laws thereof, escaping into another, shall, in consequence of any law or regulation therein, be discharged from such service or labor, but shall be delivered up on claim of the party to whom such service or labor may be due. Section 3. New states may be admitted by the Congress into this union; but no new states shall be formed or erected within the jurisdiction of any other state; nor any state be formed by the junction of two or more states, or parts of states, without the consent of the legislatures of the states concerned as well as of the Congress. The Congress shall have power to dispose of and make all needful rules and regulations respecting the territory or other property belonging to the United States; and nothing in this Constitution shall be so construed as to prejudice any claims of the United States, or of any particular state. Section 4. The United States shall guarantee to every state in this union a republican form of government, and shall protect each of them against invasion; and on application of the legislature, or of the executive (when the legislature cannot be convened) against domestic violence. ‹ Article III up Article V › U.S. Constitution Toolbox Explanation of the Constitution - from the Congressional Research Ser
perturbation.justification: The changed text designates the laws of the Principality of Sealand as governing the contract. The Perturbation Explanation notes that Sealand is not a recognized sovereign state, implying its laws lack legal standing in US courts. The Law Explanation strengthens this by mentioning the Full Faith and Credit Clause, which mandates states to respect the laws of other states, but does not extend to unrecognized entities like Sealand. Scraped Law Snippet 2 contains the text of Article IV of the U.S. Constitution, which includes the Full Faith and Credit Clause. Although the snippet doesn't explicitly exclude unrecognized entities, the Law Explanation accurately states the implied limitation, meaning the contract would be unenforceable. Therefore, selecting Sealand's laws creates a significant conflict, as those laws have no standing, and the contract becomes practically unenforceable, justifying a high contradiction score.
